Updating from 7/93/0 in light of recent results. No update from alpine skiing or cross-country skiing, since no relevant events have happened yet. Keeping 0% chance of NK medal here. In short-track speed skating, Choe Un-song disqualified from men's 1500m in the early rounds. Don't think Jong Kwang Bom has skated yet, but I predict he is worse than Choe, since he is only 16 and I can't find any record of him competing anywhere outside NK ever. Keeping the 0% forecast for this sport as well. In women's ice hockey, the most likely option has happened, namely in the preliminary group of Sweden, Switzerland, Japan, and Korea, we have Sweden and Switzerland qualified for next round and Japan + Korea eliminated [1]. It was never even close for Korea, who lost both games 8-0, and I predict will lose to Japan, but by a smaller margin (90% chance). Finally, in pairs figure skating, it looks like the NK team hasn't skated yet although for the life of me I can't figure out why, since on Fri there was an event called "pairs figure skating - short program" which is what they are registered for [2]. North Korea already has an agreement in principle to send a delegation to the Olympics. They do not have a great pedigree as far as Olympic medals and would not be participating in a huge number of events. It remains possible that the volatile leadership of DPRK could pull out before the Olympics if they believe there is a larger political goal, such as "punishing" South Korea for some perceived infraction or escalation. However, as things now stand, they have more to gain in terms of international perception and, most importantly, how they can portray the event domestically.
It seems very likely that they will send a delegation, but very unlikely that they will win a medal.

North Korean athletes are only competing in five events - women's hockey, figure skating, short track speed skating, cross-country skiing and alpine skiing. Given how strong other countries are in several of those events, however, I don't foresee a very likely path to a medal.

Updating from 10/90/0 now that we know what athletes NK will send [1]. (i) There are 2 men and 1 woman in alpine skiing (slalom and giant slalom). They seem to have no track record of winning anything, even in much smaller championships. Since there will be over 300 competitors from other countries and only 10 events [2], I'm willing to say NK has 0% chance of winning any medals in alpine skiing. (ii) In cross-country skiing there are 2 men (15km freestyle) and 1 woman (10km freestyle). They also seem to have come dead last, or near dead last, in 80+-person races in Russia last April. So I will say also 0% chance of medal for them, since there are 300+ competitors [3]. (iii) In short-track speed skating, NK is sending 2 men, but each will only compete in only one event --- Jong Kwang Bom in the 1500m and Choe Un Song in the 500m [1,4]. The latter athlete historically has times that would place him 20th or worse [5], so I'll call his chances of medalling 0%. I can't find any historical data for the former, and he is only 16 [6], so that suggests he has never competed outside NK. I give him 0% chance as well. (iv) In women's hockey we have the strange situation of the unified team. If this team does win a medal, how will the question resolve? Since each athlete gets a medal, I suppose technically a NK athlete will have won a medal, so I'll assume such medals will count for the question. I don't think this matters much though. The SK team is far from being a top team --- in the world championships they have always been division IIA or worse, and only qualified for division IB this year [7]. To be clear, the divisions are: top, IA, IB, IIA, IIB, etc. Each year the 1st-ranked team in each division is promoted to the next division up, and the bottom team is demoted to the next one down. So roughly speaking SK is "worse" than all of the top, IA, and IB divisions, or 8+6+5 = 19 teams. And indeed these divisions correlate strongly with Olympic medalling: only 6 nations have ever won medals in women's ice hockey (Canada, Finland, Russia, Sweden, Switzerland, USA) [8], and these have ALWAYS been in the top division, with the exception of Switzerland, which twice was demoted to division I but very soon got back to the top division. Now 12 NK players are joining the SK team, making their team have 35 players, but with only 22 being allowed at each game. Moreover, at every game 3 NK players must be among the 22 [1]. I'm pretty sure introducing strangers into any team, no matter how good, is very disruptive to the team. (And NK is worse than SK.) One might speculate that if the NK players were kept on the bench at all times that might not have a big effect; but that seems politically unviable to me. Plus, the Korean team is in a bracket that is already disfavored, where only the top two out of four teams go ahead to the quarter-finals [9]. On the other hand, there are only 8 teams, and half a dozen games (not all of which have to be won) between them and a medal. So I don't feel like the chance is 0%. I'll give it 5%. (v) Finally, in figure skating, NK is only entering the pairs event [10]. The most recent benchmark we can look at is how the NK pair placed in the Helsinki tournament in 2017 [11]. They came in 15th, and of the pairs that beat them, I can spot at least 10 in Pyeongchang [12], with possibly more to come from China and Russia. Let us generously assume that NK has a 50/50 chance of beating any of those 10 pairs. In order to medal, they would need to beat at least 8 of them. The odds of that are: 0.5^10 + (10 choose 1)*0.5^10 + (10 choose 2)*0.5^10 ~ 5%. But they don't have a uniform 50/50 chance of beating any of these pairs; for instance the competitors from Russia and China are on a whole other level. Plus looking at these 10 pairs doesn't take into account all the others. So I bring these odds down to 2%. Final fore cast: 7% chance of medal, 93% chance of going but no medal. [1] https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/olympics/medals-unlikely-as-22-north-koreans-head-to-winter-olympics/2018/01/20/86578ba0-fe04-11e7-9b5d-bbf0da31214d_story.html
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alpine_skiing_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics
[3] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross-country_skiing_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics
[4] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Short_track_speed_skating_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Qualification
[5] http://www.shorttrackonline.info/skaterbio.php?id=STPRK10712199201
[6] http://www.shorttrackonline.info/skaterbio.php?id=STPRK12907200101
[7] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Korea_women%27s_national_ice_hockey_team#World_Championships
[8] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ice_hockey_at_the_Olympic_Games#Participating_nations
[9] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ice_hockey_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_tournament#Preliminary_round
[10] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Figure_skating_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics
[11] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_World_Figure_Skating_Championships#Pairs
[12] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Figure_skating_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics#Entries

Broadly, North Korea does make a point of participating in the Olympic Games, though they're significantly more successful/consistent at the Summer versus Winter Games. The high-level talks between North and South Korea revolving around the North Korean pairs figure skating couple appears to illustrate dedicated intent to participate, and given the risks of participation (athlete defection) vice rewards (international profile of the Games; solidarity with IOC) for the DPRK, it seems more than likely they'll participate, though there's always a chance that talks could break down and the athletes don't make it to the games.  Medal likelihood seems nil given the world ranking of the DPRK pairs team relative to other pairs competing at the games, and the relatively fewer opportunities for surprises/upsets in pairs figure skating, i.e. if the sport were short track speed skating, where entire heats of skaters may fall or be disqualified, the odds of a freak accident leading to a DPRK medal are more likely than the number of accidents/mistakes that would have to occur to allow a pairs figure skating team to be elevated in the same way.

https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/09/sports/olympics/north-korea-olympics.html?emc=edit_mbe_20180110&nl=morning-briefing-europe&nlid=77825025&te=1 Ryom Tae-ok and Kim Ju-sik of North Korea are not expected to win a medal in pairs figure skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics in South Korea. But few athletes may have a more impactful presence next month at the Games . . .  after North Korea announced Tuesday that it would participate in the Games. The pairs team, which finished 15th at the world skating championships last year .  . .  are the only North Koreans who have qualified for the 2018 Games. They are the lone elite, world-class winter athletes from the isolated nation, which has only won two medals at the Winter Games, a silver and bronze in speedskating, the last coming in 1992, and they have plenty of admirers among figure skating’s cognoscenti. “They are so charismatic; I know the crowd would fall for them with their smile and passion and love of skating,” Bruno Marcotte, a prominent Canadian pairs coach who worked with the skaters last summer in Montreal and during an Olympic qualifying competition in Germany in September, said by phone on Tuesday. “I feel they’ll be a crowd favorite.”
. . . 
. . . on various fields of play, the two countries have been on convivial terms lately. Last year, North Korea sent its women’s national hockey team to play in South Korea, and South Korea sent its women’s soccer team to play in North Korea. North Korea also sent a taekwondo team to the South. The two nations marched together in the opening ceremony at the 2000 and 2004 Summer Olympics. South Korean officials have held open that possibility for the Winter Games.
. . . 
North Korea missed a deadline in late October to officially enter its pairs team into the Olympics. And it does not yet appear to have made such a request, Alexander Lakernik, a Russian who is vice president of the International Skating Union, said in a telephone interview on Tuesday. But adding the North Koreans to the Olympic pairs competition would be a simple procedure. And the I.O.C. has said it would keep the doors open to North Korea’s participation for as long as possible. The Olympic committee has also broached the idea of offering North Korea wild-card entries in some Nordic skiing sports and short-track speedskating. Discussions have been underway about the pairs team, Mr. Lakernik said, and given the special circumstances, “there could be an exception made; but first we need an application.” While North Korea has won 16 gold medals in the Summer Games, in such sports as weight lifting, wrestling and boxing, it is not a power in the more expensive winter sports. North Korea did not participate in the 2014 Winter Games in Sochi, Russia. Its officials have recently complained that tightened sanctions against the country have made it difficult to obtain some sports equipment. In general, North Korea has not appeared to follow the model of the former Soviet Union and East Germany, which were both winter sports powers and used gold medals for propaganda purposes. But experts see participation in these Games as an attempt by Mr. Kim to get sanctions eased and to reduce the chances of American military action. “Sports diplomacy is a sexy affair,” said Lee Sung-yoon, a Korea expert at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University. “Pyongyang has all the reason to jazz up the Winter Olympiad and be the center of attention.” Purely in skating terms, Mr. Marcotte, the coach said, the North Koreans appear to be mirroring the Chinese model of attempting to build pairs teams to an elite international level. At the 2006 and 2010 Winter Olympics, Chinese pairs won two of the three available medals and are among the favorites to win gold at the 2018 Games. Ryom and Kim possess some of the dynamism seen in Chinese pairs and also some of the classic, balletic style of Russian skaters. There is Western influence in their routines as well. They perform their short program to an instrumental version of the Beatles’ “A Day in the Life.” While qualifying for the 2018 Games at a competition in Germany in September, the skaters spoke several times with reporters and seemed relatively open. Both Ryom and Kim are listed as students. Both live in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, where loyalists to the Kim Jong-un regime are permitted to reside. “I want to continue to improve until I become world champion,” Ryom said at the time. One subject was off limits: the Olympics, because no decision had yet been made about North Korea’s participation. And there seemed to be every attempt to avoid politics. Neither skater, for instance, wore pins commonly worn by North Koreans that depict Kim Il-sung and Kim Jong-il, Kim Jong-un’s grandfather and father, who preceded him as the country’s dynastic rulers. And both skaters neglected to praise Kim Jong-un for their success, another common practice for North Korean athletes. Mr. Marcotte, the coach, said that all his interactions with the skaters had been about “sports, sports, sports.” And while their performance at the Olympics would carry broader meaning for many, he said, the skaters would most likely feel only the pressure that every skater feels — to perform at their best. “They want to show the world that they’re a good team,” Mr. Marcotte said.

I predict it is most likely that PRK will send a delegation to the PyeongChang Winter Olympics but will not win a medal (84%). I predict there to be a 12% chance that PRK sends athletes to PyeongChang it will win medal(s). I continue to see there to be a 4% chance that PKR will revers it’s decision to send a delegation to the Olympic Games. Base rates:
•	I used the the number of Winter Olympics PRK could have participated as PRK (14 Winter games) and the number of medals it has achieved to win at the Winter Olympics (2 medals).
o	All things equal PRK has 14% chance (2/14=0,1428) of winning a medal at any Winter Olympic games.
•	However I assume there to be a 5% chance of both PKR figure skaters or a hidden-gem bringing a medal to PKR
o	1-0.04 (no participation)*0,05 = 0,048 ≈ 5%. Added probability thus of a medal would be 10%
•	Average of the two base rates would be 12%. Key Facts:
•	North Korea and South Korea have held talks and allegedly have agreed that PKR will send official sports delegation to participate in the 2018 Winter Olympics in PyeongChang.
•	PKR has in history won two medals from Winter Olypmics both from speed skating – silver in 1964 and bronze in 1992.
•	PRK athlets are training in cross country skiing and ice skating categories (figure skating & speed skating).
Key Assumptions:
•	I assume the figure skaters that we know of which PRK is planning on sending to Olympics are unlikely to achieve a much better result they achieved at last world championships – 15th. The likelihood of such a team winning a medal is 5%.
•	I assume there is a likelihood of a „hidden gem“/wild card that could bring PRK a medal on a certain event – 5% chance.
•	I assume there still to be a chance that PRK will reverse its decision to not send a delegation to the Olympic games. Key Indicators:
•	Good times/performance by PRK athlets at qualification rounds would increase the likelihood of PRK taking a medal from these Olympic games.
•	PRK athlets mulling through qualification rounds or disqualifying in these rounds on diferent sports events. Decrease of the likelihood of PRK taking medals home from these Olympic games.
•	Each week passing that nears to the opening ceremony will decrease the „No“ likelihood by 1%. Links:

The following factors influenced my answer: -N. Korea has only ever won 2 Winter Olympic medals (1992 + 1964).

Now there's been a very favorable response from SK, apparent blessing from US for Olympics-related contact at least, and now another response from NK, reopening the phone line that's been historically used for communication [2]. Yes and medals:
North Korea has won only two medals in Winter Olympics in the past out of 8. I don't use 2/8 or 25% as a prior because the qualifying athletes scored 6th in the pairs at the Nebelhorn and NK missed the qualifiers for Sochi [1]. Plus it's a conditional probability of going in the first place. 
[1] http://www.espn.com/olympics/story/_/id/20866722/north-korean-skaters-qualify-18-winter-olympic-games-pyeongchang Yes and no medals:
North Korea actually cares a LOT about the Olympics. Athletes are given special treatment tied to their outcomes, delegations are sent with official news crews, officials brag about performance, and they even sent officials to Sochi even though they didn't qualify (very narrowly) [1]. This year, two qualified, and I would rate this higher, except that they missed the December deadline to send them in. Nonetheless, the IOC and South Korea repeatedly talk about how much they want NK to just send them in and how they would make special exceptions for them [2]. NK is making a lot of international headlines, so they probably want to stay in the spotlight.
[1] https://pjmedia.com/claudiarosett/nork-olympics-without-athletes/
[2] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-olympics-2018-northkorea/north-korea-decision-on-olympics-participation-seen-as-last-minute-south-korea-official-idUSKBN1DE2TS No:
As stated, they missed the deadline despite qualifying. It's also possible that KJU sees the potential embarrassment of sending a delegation that will not win and so is purposefully not sending them in, but that assumes he is accurately assessing the likelihood of a win. It's also strangely hard to find out why they missed 2002.

The Olympics are being held in South Korea, so logistics aren't an obstacle.  The Olympics (are supposed to) have an aspect of diplomacy, and South Korea is more willing to make exceptions than a host without a stake in the conflict between NK and SK.  It's a path for NK to make diplomatic overtures without appearing to capitulate to international pressure. They also are under a lot of economic stress due to international sanctions and have advanced their weapons program to the point of being a potential nuclear deterrent. The Olympics themselves seemed headed to be a flop, with a lot of unsold tickets portending low attendance. SK had a lot of incentive to try to temporarily defuse tensions if they wanted to have a successful event and be seen as a host for games in the future. The main development for me was when SK started expressing that they wanted to postpone military exercises with the USA, which NK had been raising as an obstacle to participation. The US Defense Secretary's response was less than ideal, but did leave a subtle opening for delay. The dates for the exercises were also not public (AFAIK) so they could set a later date while claiming that there had been no delay. As far as medals, this pair seems to have placed in some recent past skating events, giving them a small chance.

"The North's leader, Kim Jong-un, said earlier he was considering sending a team to Pyeongchang in South Korea for the Games in February." Updating from 1/39/60 [1] due to breaking news from Kim Jong-Un and a somewhat embarrassing math error on my part. First, Kim Jong-Un has suggested quite clearly in his New Year's address that NK is willing to send a delegation to the Winter Olympics [2,3].  Since SK and everyone else had been bending over backwards to get them to come, they won't object. It comes down to what demands Kim Jong-Un makes. The crowd (158 forecasters as of this writing) has "No" at 47%, while professor Yang Moo-Jin of the University of North Korean Studies in Seoul told AFP "The chances of the North coming to the Olympics now seem to be more than 80 percent" [2] . I have no idea how calibrated prof Yang is but he is an expert in the area. For now I will go in between the crowd and prof Yang and call "No" 30%. What about medaling? In [1] I counted NK participation in 69 WO events, with 2 medals, which gives 2/69 ~ 3% chance of medal per event. (And not 1.5% as I claimed in [1].)  Bump that up to 4% since Russia is out of these WO. NK only qualified for pairs figure skating but Lee Hee-Beom, the head of the Pyeongchang Organising Committee for the Olympic Games, said "North Korea is likely to send athletes to figure skating, short track skating, cross country and women's ice hockey". [2] Assuming that means athletes of both genders for SSS and CC, and both genders plus pair for FS, that would suggest participation in 8 events, giving 1 - (1 - 0.03)^8 ~ 22% chance of medal. But athletes not in FS didn't qualify, so they are worse than average, so bring that down by 2/3, 14%. Overall that means 70% x 14% ~ 10% chance of medal, leaving 60% chance of going but no medal. Thanks to @Win10d, @Prognosticating-Beek, and @Raisinville for the info on  Kim Jong-Un's New Year speech. [1] http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/644021

[3] https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-01-01/north-korea-s-olympics-peace-bid-tests-u-s-south-korea-alliance

PRK's application for its two qualifying skaters missed the deadline, so participation will require special dispensation by the IOC. There is no available evidence of precedent. Following Kim’s new year speech, in which he stated that he hoped the Olympics is a success, the probability of participation rises - Moon can use the olympics to partially defuse tension. Still, the chances of the pair winning are exceptionally low - PRK's last medal in the winter olympics was 1992, and they have never won a figure skating medal. The qualifying figure skating pair did win bronze at the 2017 Asian Winter Games. However, figure skating is dominated by European and North American participants, with the Asian exception being China.
I think sports will try to circumvent politics between individual countries. NK on some level, just wants to be treated normally, but also wants to be left alone.
Sending a delegation of athletes in time would be an almost unprecedented cooldown speed.

NK will agree to send its two qualifying figure skaters once the US agrees with SK to delay the war games which would have coincided with the Olympics this year. However, as there will only be the two athletes, the odds of them medaling in their very competitive event are slim.

North Korea has not participated in 7 of the last 14 Winter Olympics, including the last one in Sochi. With the current state of affairs and the fact that they only won medals in 2 of the seven they participate in, I believe they will choose not to participate in this one.

Based off of 1988 boycott historical precident, the intentional missing of the 31OCT deadline for their qualified figure skaters, and the current political tensions they will boycott. On the other hand, they did participate in the asian games in 2017 in Japan and they do like pomp and ceremony when they win. On the 3d hand this is a great opportunity to hijack the news with all the media present, so they may have no delegates but instead launch a missile or two over japan.

While the conflict between the two countries is long standing, North Korea has had good showings in the last few Olympics. As a world power, attending the Olympics and having a good showing is a matter of pride.  If NK can win a medal in SK, what a matter of pride!
Why they shouldn't? They won't start a war, USA either.
The games are in South Korea and to send one would legitimize their existence, also the likelihood of a defection by team members would be quite high.

The qualifying athletes gives them the ability to be seen on an international stage and  the ability to gloat if they do well.  If the athletes are injured or non-competitive, they may want to save face by staying out of the contest. The athletes may also be viewed as a defection risk, which would motivate Pyongyang to forbid participation.

I made a 8/18/74 just yesterday [1] but this Q has been on my mind and I've had a couple new thoughts, so I'm updating. On the yes/no front, it struck me that NK has apparently never said it would NOT go to the games. In contrast, when they did boycott the 1988 games, they announced those plans 8 months in advance [2]. In addition, there was news today of a rather strong signal from SK that it wants NK to participate, and some mildly favorable response from NK [3]. Based on these, I'm gonna go substantially below the crowd and call "no" a 60%. On the other hand, I did more precise calculations on probability of medals, by looking at number of Olympic events NK has participated in, rather than just number of Winter Olympics. From Wikipedia [4] one gathers that NK has participated in 69 events at the WO overall, and won 2 medals. This makes ~1.5% chance of medal per event. And in the 2018 WO they are qualified for only 1 event. But again, Russia is out, so bump that up to 2%. This makes chance of medal 0.4*0.02 ~ 1%, leaving 39% chance of participating but no medal. [1] http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/643100
[2] http://www.nytimes.com/1988/01/16/sports/cubans-turn-their-back-on-the-seoul-olympics.html
[3] https://www.nbcnews.com/news/north-korea/north-korea-tensions-south-urges-u-s-delay-military-drills-n831011
[4] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Korea_at_the_Olympics
North Korea does not acknowledge the legitimacy of South Korea. Participating would belie that position.

This is a tough one. North Korea has never boycotted the Winter Olympics [1] (it has only failed to qualify, on some occasions). It has boycotted the Summer Olympics twice [1] but in what feels like different times: in 1984 (in USA, when lots of communist countries boycotted), and in 1988 (in South Korea, when the IOC denied NK's request to co-host). For this question, we have (i) NK athletes already qualified; (ii) no large boycott from a bloc of countries; and (iii) no request to co-host from NK. These would all point to "yes". Another baserate-type argument for "yes" is the fact that NK routinely participates in sporting events in SK, e.g. the 2002 and 2014 Asian Games [2]. Pointing to "no" we have the current tensions in the peninsula, and the fact that NK has missed the deadline to accept the spots for which they have qualified --- by 49 days, as of this writing. Pointing back to "yes" we have the IOC signalling very hard that it wants NK in the Winter Olympics in spite of the missed deadline --- “We are still working to get North Korean athletes to participate – as you know two skaters are qualified but have missed the deadline,” said IOC spokesman Mark Adams. “But we would of course be flexible if they expressed a desire to come” [3]. I believe this means the window hasn't really closed, and won't really close until maybe the week before the event (early Feb), and moreover NK probably knows this, somewhat nullifying the deadline concerns above. Pointing back to "no" we have the crowd consensus here on GJOpen, which currently stands at 85% "no" with 49 forecasters chiming in. This is worrisome, because my feeling from other considerations is that "no" should be below 50%. But I hesitate a lot to call the crowd wrong. Finally: is being in the Olympics good or bad for Kim Jong-un (presumably the person who makes this decision)? The Olympics generate national pride in people, which I imagine to be a pro for him. And I can't see a con of the same clarity and magnitude. What does he gain by staying out? In 1988 I can see the boycott being motivated by face-saving --- presumably NK people were aware that NK was asking to co-host, and ultimately failed. Nothing like that this time. So this Kim Jong-un pro/con viewpoint also weakly points to "yes". So, out of respect for the crowd, I'm going to give "yes" the highest probability the crowd has ever given it: 26%. Now what are the odds of medal? NK has been in 8 Winter Olympics, winning medals in 2 of them. This makes 25% chance. But Russia is out of these WO, so bump that up to 30%. So 0.26*0.3 ~ 8% chance of medal, and 18% chance of participating but no medal. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Korea_at_the_Olympics
[2] http://olympics.nbcsports.com/2017/04/03/north-korea-pyeongchang-olympics-2018/
[3] https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/olympics/2017/12/10/ioc-encouraging-north-korean-athletes-compete-pyeongchang/938637001/

That said, North Korean athletes have qualified for figure skating at least (maybe others, I didn't get deep) and the IOC has encouraged the country to participate. They don't have much to lose but I think it is slightly more likely than not that NK ends up boycotting the games.
